nexttext:
\begin{dfn}  A 4-dimensional submanifold $X$ of a $Spin(7)$ manifold $(N,\Psi)$ is
called {\em Cayley} if $\Psi|_X\equiv vol(X)$. 
\end{dfn}


\vspace{.05in}

Analogous to the $G_2$ case, we introduce a tangent bundle-valued
$3$-form, which is simply the triple cross product of $N$.

\begin{dfn}  Let $(N, \Psi )$ be a $Spin(7)$ manifold. Then $\Upsilon \in
\Omega^{3}(N, TN)$ is the tangent bundle-valued 3-form defined by
the identity:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Psi(u,v,w,z)=\langle u\times v\times w,z\rangle." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>w</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\begin{dfn}  A 4-dimensional submanifold $X$ of a $Spin(7)$ manifold $(N,\Psi)$ is
called {\em Cayley} if $\Psi|_X\equiv vol(X)$. 
\end{dfn}


\vspace{.05in}

Analogous to the $G_2$ case, we introduce a tangent bundle-valued
$3$-form, which is simply the triple cross product of $N$.

\begin{dfn}  Let $(N, \Psi )$ be a $Spin(7)$ manifold. Then $\Upsilon \in
\Omega^{3}(N, TN)$ is the tangent bundle-valued 3-form defined by
the identity:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\langle\tau(u,v,w),z\rangle=\Psi(u,v,w,z)=\langle u\times v\times w,z\rangle." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>w</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>w</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent which is a self dual $4$-form, and the corresponding tangent bundle-valued 3-form is
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1X.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\Psi=\;\;e^{1234}" display="inline"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo rspace="8.1pt">=</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>1234</mn></msup></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1X.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle+(e^{12}-e^{34})\wedge(e^{56}-e^{78})" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>12</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>34</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∧</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>56</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>78</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1Xa.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle+(e^{13}+e^{24})\wedge(e^{57}+e^{68})" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>13</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>24</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∧</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>57</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>68</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1Xb.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle+(e^{14}-e^{23})\wedge(e^{58}-e^{67})+e^{5678}," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>14</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>23</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∧</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>58</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>67</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mn>5678</mn></msup></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\vspace{.1in}

Since $\Psi$ is self-dual, L-submanifolds are not in the complement space of Cayley submanifolds (unlike their $G_2$ counterparts Harvey-Lawson submanifolds).  However, similar to Harvey-Lawson manifolds, we can use a vector-valued form to define them.  


There is a natural vector bundle $V$ on a $Spin(7)$ manifold given by $V = E \times_{\rho} \mathbb{R}^7$, where $E$ is the principal coframe bundle on $N$ and $\rho$ is the representation of $Spin(7)$ on $\mathbb{R}^7$ induced from the standard representation of $SO(7)$ on $\mathbb{R}^7$.  Further, we can define a $V$-valued $4$-form $\eta$ that vanishes identically on the Cayley submanifolds of $N$.  As shown in \cite{mclean}, this form, $\eta$, can be locally given by the components


\begin{eqnarray*}( -e^{1567}-e^{1347} - e^{1246} + e^{1235} + e^{2348} + e^{2568} + e^{3578} - e^{4678}), \\
(-e^{2567} - e^{2347} + e^{1236} + e^{1245}- e^{1348}- e^{1568} + e^{4578}+ e^{3678}), \\
(-e^{3567} + e^{1237} + e^{2346} + e^{1345}+ e^{1248} - e^{4568} - e^{1578}- e^{2678}), \\
(-e^{4567} +e^{1247} - e^{1346} + e^{2345}- e^{1238}+ e^{3568} - e^{2578} + e^{1678}), \\
(-e^{3457} + e^{1257} - e^{2456} - e^{1356}+ e^{1268} - e^{3468}+ e^{1378} + e^{2478}),  \\
(-e^{3467}+ e^{1267}- e^{2356}+ e^{1456}- e^{1258} + e^{3458} - e^{1478}+ e^{2378}), \\
(e^{2467} + e^{1367} - e^{2357} + e^{1457}- e^{1358} - e^{2458} + e^{1468}- e^{2368}). \end{eqnarray*}
One can check that a four-dimensional manifold is an $L$-submanifold if and only if

nexttext: Note that this is equivalent to the Cayley inequality as given in \cite{HL}:
prevtext:
\vspace{.1in}

Since $\Psi$ is self-dual, L-submanifolds are not in the complement space of Cayley submanifolds (unlike their $G_2$ counterparts Harvey-Lawson submanifolds).  However, similar to Harvey-Lawson manifolds, we can use a vector-valued form to define them.  


There is a natural vector bundle $V$ on a $Spin(7)$ manifold given by $V = E \times_{\rho} \mathbb{R}^7$, where $E$ is the principal coframe bundle on $N$ and $\rho$ is the representation of $Spin(7)$ on $\mathbb{R}^7$ induced from the standard representation of $SO(7)$ on $\mathbb{R}^7$.  Further, we can define a $V$-valued $4$-form $\eta$ that vanishes identically on the Cayley submanifolds of $N$.  As shown in \cite{mclean}, this form, $\eta$, can be locally given by the components


\begin{eqnarray*}( -e^{1567}-e^{1347} - e^{1246} + e^{1235} + e^{2348} + e^{2568} + e^{3578} - e^{4678}), \\
(-e^{2567} - e^{2347} + e^{1236} + e^{1245}- e^{1348}- e^{1568} + e^{4578}+ e^{3678}), \\
(-e^{3567} + e^{1237} + e^{2346} + e^{1345}+ e^{1248} - e^{4568} - e^{1578}- e^{2678}), \\
(-e^{4567} +e^{1247} - e^{1346} + e^{2345}- e^{1238}+ e^{3568} - e^{2578} + e^{1678}), \\
(-e^{3457} + e^{1257} - e^{2456} - e^{1356}+ e^{1268} - e^{3468}+ e^{1378} + e^{2478}),  \\
(-e^{3467}+ e^{1267}- e^{2356}+ e^{1456}- e^{1258} + e^{3458} - e^{1478}+ e^{2378}), \\
(e^{2467} + e^{1367} - e^{2357} + e^{1457}- e^{1358} - e^{2458} + e^{1468}- e^{2368}). \end{eqnarray*}
One can check that a four-dimensional manifold is an $L$-submanifold if and only if
Note that this is equivalent to the Cayley inequality as given in \cite{HL}:
text: \[ \Psi(u,v,w,z)^2 + |\eta( u\times v\times w\times z)|^2 = |u\wedge v\wedge w\wedge z |^2 .\]
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Psi(u,v,w,z)^{2}+|\eta(u\times v\times w\times z)|^{2}=|u\wedge v\wedge w%
\wedge z|^{2}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>∧</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>∧</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>∧</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\pagebreak

\begin{lem} The following properties hold:

\begin{itemize}

\item[(a)]  If  ${\mathbb E}=< u,v,w,z>$ is an $L$-plane field, then

is also an $L$-plane field. 

\item[(b)] ${\mathbb E} \perp {\mathbb V}$.
 \item[(c)] $\{u,v,w, z, R_{uvw}, R_{uvz}, R_{uwz}, R_{vwz} \}$ is an orthonormal frame field on $N$.
\end{itemize}
\end{lem}


 \vspace{.1in}

In particular we can express $\Psi$ as

\begin{eqnarray*} \Psi & = & u\wedge v\wedge w \wedge (u\times v\times w) \\
& & + [ u\wedge v- w\wedge (u\times v \times w)] \wedge [ z\wedge (u\times v\times z) - (u\times w\times z) \wedge (v\times w \times z)] \\
& & + [u\wedge w + v\wedge (u\times v \times w)] \wedge[ z\wedge (u\times w \times z) + (u\times v\times z)\wedge (v\times w\times z) ]\\
& & + [u\wedge (u\times v\times w) - v\wedge w ] \wedge [ z\wedge (v\wedge w \wedge z) - (u\wedge v\wedge z) \wedge (u\wedge w\wedge z)] \\
& & + z \wedge (u\wedge v\wedge z) \wedge (u\wedge w\wedge z) \wedge (v\wedge w\wedge z) .\end{eqnarray*}
Rewriting this form in terms of our vector fields, we have

\begin{eqnarray*} \Psi &= &u\wedge v\wedge w \wedge R_{uvw}\\
& & + [u\wedge v-w\wedge R_{uvw}] \wedge [ z\wedge R_{uvz} - R_{uwz} \wedge R_{vwz} ] \\
& & + [u\wedge w + v\wedge R_{uvw}] \wedge[ z\wedge R_{uwz} + R_{uvz} \wedge R_{vwz} ] \\
& & + [u\wedge R_{uvw} - v\wedge w ] \wedge [z\wedge R_{vwz} - R_{uvz} \wedge R_{uwz}]\\
& & + z\wedge R_{uvz} \wedge R_{uwz} \wedge R_{vwz} .\end{eqnarray*}
Since
prevtext:
\pagebreak

\begin{lem} The following properties hold:

\begin{itemize}

\item[(a)]  If  ${\mathbb E}=< u,v,w,z>$ is an $L$-plane field, then

is also an $L$-plane field. 

\item[(b)] ${\mathbb E} \perp {\mathbb V}$.
 \item[(c)] $\{u,v,w, z, R_{uvw}, R_{uvz}, R_{uwz}, R_{vwz} \}$ is an orthonormal frame field on $N$.
\end{itemize}
\end{lem}


 \vspace{.1in}

In particular we can express $\Psi$ as

\begin{eqnarray*} \Psi & = & u\wedge v\wedge w \wedge (u\times v\times w) \\
& & + [ u\wedge v- w\wedge (u\times v \times w)] \wedge [ z\wedge (u\times v\times z) - (u\times w\times z) \wedge (v\times w \times z)] \\
& & + [u\wedge w + v\wedge (u\times v \times w)] \wedge[ z\wedge (u\times w \times z) + (u\times v\times z)\wedge (v\times w\times z) ]\\
& & + [u\wedge (u\times v\times w) - v\wedge w ] \wedge [ z\wedge (v\wedge w \wedge z) - (u\wedge v\wedge z) \wedge (u\wedge w\wedge z)] \\
& & + z \wedge (u\wedge v\wedge z) \wedge (u\wedge w\wedge z) \wedge (v\wedge w\wedge z) .\end{eqnarray*}
Rewriting this form in terms of our vector fields, we have

\begin{eqnarray*} \Psi &= &u\wedge v\wedge w \wedge R_{uvw}\\
& & + [u\wedge v-w\wedge R_{uvw}] \wedge [ z\wedge R_{uvz} - R_{uwz} \wedge R_{vwz} ] \\
& & + [u\wedge w + v\wedge R_{uvw}] \wedge[ z\wedge R_{uwz} + R_{uvz} \wedge R_{vwz} ] \\
& & + [u\wedge R_{uvw} - v\wedge w ] \wedge [z\wedge R_{vwz} - R_{uvz} \wedge R_{uwz}]\\
& & + z\wedge R_{uvz} \wedge R_{uwz} \wedge R_{vwz} .\end{eqnarray*}
Since
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\langle\tau(u,v,w),z\rangle=\Psi(u,v,w,z)=\langle u\times v\times w,z\rangle=0" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>w</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>w</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Further, the map $F$ is the restriction of $\Psi$ to $L_{V}$ and then pulled back to $L$ via $(\exp_V)^*$, where
$\exp_V$ is the normal exponential map that takes $L$ diffeomorphically
onto its image $L_V$ in a neighborhood around 0.


\vspace{.1in}
We can naturally identify normal vector fields to $L$ with differential
$3$-forms on $L$.  Further, since $L$ is compact, these normal
vector fields can be identified with nearby submanifolds.  Thus, the kernel of $F$ corresponds to deformations of $L$.


\vspace{.1in}

The linearization of $F$ at $(0)$ is given by
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}&\displaystyle F:\Gamma(N(L))\rightarrow\Lambda^{3}T^{*}(L),\\
&\displaystyle F(V)=((\exp_{V})^{*}(\Psi|_{L_{V}})).\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>:</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>→</mo><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>T</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>exp</mi><mi>V</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><msub><mi>L</mi><mi>V</mi></msub></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

prevtext:
Further, the map $F$ is the restriction of $\Psi$ to $L_{V}$ and then pulled back to $L$ via $(\exp_V)^*$, where
$\exp_V$ is the normal exponential map that takes $L$ diffeomorphically
onto its image $L_V$ in a neighborhood around 0.


\vspace{.1in}
We can naturally identify normal vector fields to $L$ with differential
$3$-forms on $L$.  Further, since $L$ is compact, these normal
vector fields can be identified with nearby submanifolds.  Thus, the kernel of $F$ corresponds to deformations of $L$.


\vspace{.1in}

The linearization of $F$ at $(0)$ is given by
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="dF(0):\Gamma(N(L))\rightarrow\Lambda^{3}T^{*}(L)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>→</mo><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>T</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\vspace{.1in}

Further, by Cartan's formula, we have
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle dF(0)(V)=&\displaystyle\frac{\displaystyle\partial}%
{\displaystyle\partial{t}}F(tV)|_{t=0}=\frac{\displaystyle\partial}{%
\displaystyle\partial{t}}[\exp_{tV}^{*}(\Psi)]\\
\displaystyle=&\displaystyle[{\mathcal{L}}_{V}(\Psi)|_{L}].\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi/></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mo>∂</mo><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mo>∂</mo><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>exp</mi><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow><mo>*</mo></msubsup><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mrow><mrow><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mi>V</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mi>L</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext:
where $i_V$ represents the interior derivative, $v$ is the dual
$3$-form to the vector field $V$ with respect to the induced
metric, and $\star v$ is the Hodge dual of $v$ on L. Hence
prevtext:
\vspace{.1in}

Further, by Cartan's formula, we have
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle dF(0)(V)&\displaystyle=((i_{V}d\Psi+d(i_{V}\Psi))|_%
{L}\\
&\displaystyle=d(i_{V}\Psi)|_{L}=(d\star v),\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>i</mi><mi>V</mi></msub><mi>d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>d</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>i</mi><mi>V</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>L</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>i</mi><mi>V</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mi>L</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⋆</mo><mi>v</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

prevtext:
where $i_V$ represents the interior derivative, $v$ is the dual
$3$-form to the vector field $V$ with respect to the induced
metric, and $\star v$ is the Hodge dual of $v$ on L. Hence
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="dF(0)(V)=(d\star v)=(d^{*}v)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⋆</mo><mi>v</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>v</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
for all $u, v\in TS$.  As a final remark, we note that we can construct analogous structures for Harvey-Lawson and RS submanifolds (as submanifolds of a $G_2$ manifold) and $L$-submanifolds (as submanifolds of a $Spin(7)$ manifold).  

Given a Harvey-Lawson submanifold $HL$ of a $G_2$ manifold $(M, \varphi)$, we can show that the cross product $\times$ acts as this almost complex structure on $M$.  Further, given an RS-submanifold of $M$, the vector-valued $3$-form $\chi$, given by $\chi(u,v,w) = -u\times(v\times w)$ assumes this role, taking tangent vectors on the RS submanifold to normal vectors. Finally, given an $L$-submanifolds of a $Spin(7)$ manifold $(N, \Psi)$, the vector-valued 3-form $\tau$ takes tangent vectors on the $L$-submanifold to normal vectors and thus acts as an almost complex structure in this case.
\end{rem}

This is the second part of work that was done when the second author was visiting Cornell University as the Ruth I. Michler Fellow during the Spring of 2015. Many thanks to the mathematics department at Cornell for their hospitality and AWM for their support during the course of this work.}
